BREACH OF PRIVILEGE
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: I have found the time to read through the Memorandum addressed to all Honourable Members by the Chairman of the Singapore Trade Unions Working Committee (Committee of Liaison Officers of Trade Unions) and dated the 25th June, 1962.

    Although I have as yet received no complaint by any Member of a breach of privilege, it is my duty as Speaker and guardian of the privileges of Honourable Members and of this House to sound a note of warning to all who wish to address Honourablc Members in any matter.

    It is well established that it is a breach of privilege for any person to do anything which tends to impair, impede or fetter the free judgment or actions of any Member in the services he gives to this Assembly.

    The Memorandum contains certain passages which may well be construed to be an attempt to influence by veiled threats Government Back Benchers in their free judgment and conduct in relation to the Referendum Bill and matters connected therewith. If that is so, then there has been a grave breach of privilege and the offenders, if found guilty, would be liable to heavy penalties laid down in the Legislative Assembly (Privileges, Immunities and Powers) Ordinance, 1962.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PUBLICATION OF PROPOSED CONSTITUTION
IMPLEMENTING PAPER COMMAND 33 OF 1961


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister (a) when it is anticipated that the proposed Constitution implementing Paper Command 33 of 1961 will be published: and (b) whether he will

Column: 150

consider putting the issue of closer relations with the Federation to a referen dum after the publication of the proposed Constitution.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, the constitutional provisions to give effect to Paper Command 33 of 1961 will be published for implementation after the people have expressed their choice on the mode and manner of the inevitable reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya. If the people's choice is for a merger with local autonomy for Singapore, particularly in respect of education and labour, then the implementation of Paper Command No. 33 of 1961 will be proceeded with.

    Sir, the suggestion of the Member for Anson appears to be reversing the or dinary chronological order of events, for in the unlikely event of the majority of the people supporting the complete merger proposals like Penang or Malacca, US has been proposed by the Barisan Sosialis, or like Johore as has been pro posed by the United People's Party, or like one of the States in the present Federation in complete and unconditional merger as proposed by the Workers' Party, the task would then be a relatively easy one of Simply including Singapore in the present framework of the Constitution of the Federation of Malaya.

    Mr David Marshall: Does the Prime Minister not consider that the publication of the draft Constitution spelling out the agreement would assist the people in understanding exactly what is intended and help them in making up their minds for the purpose of voting at the referendum poll?

    The Prime Minister: With great respect, Mr Speaker, Sir, I would say that there is no surer way of adding confusion than to put in formal constitutional language the provision& which have been spelled out in ordinary simple language in the heads of agreement contained in Command Paper No 33 of 1961. I think the Member for Anson will remember that the constitutional arrangements that he arrived at in 1956 although uncompleted certainly made

Column: 151

easier reading and easier understanding than the ultimate Order in Council which embodied nearly all the provisions to which he agreed in 1956 other than the articles or sections for the Internal Security Council.

    Mr David Marshall: Would the Prime Minister not consider that in the light of experience and procedure in Australia and Switzerland among other countries, that the mode should be to call for a referendum after the proposals in precise form have had the approval of Parliament?

    Mr Speaker: The Prime Minister has answered it.

    The Prime Minister: I think it is necessary so far as I can that I should leave the Member for Anson under no misapprehension on this matter. I would say that it is the duty of any Government to ensure that things are presented simply and clearly to the people. As the Member for Anson himself knows, eminent legislators like the Member for Queenstown can make grave errors as to the meaning of merger like Penang and Malacca. The Member for Anson has had occasion to withdraw on behalf of the Member for Queenstown the proposals set out by the Member for Queenstown, all because he misconstrued the Federation Constitution to mean what he thought he could make it mean. I do not know about the comprehension range of the people of Australia or New Zealand on the English language, particularly for legal forms and precedents, but in our circumstances and in our clime, I suggest that we had better speak in simple, precise amid easy language - monosyllabic if possible - so that everybody can understand what is intended, and let the lawyers who are men trained for these jobs, legal draftsmen and parliamentary draftsmen to execute our intentions.

APPLICATION OF LABOUR ORDINANCE TO DOMESTIC SERVANTS


    2. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Labour whether Government will consider applying the Labour Ordinance to domestic servants.

Column: 152



    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Wee Toon Boon) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am asked to reply. This matter has been receiving attention for a considerable time in view of the need to be sure that no unrealistic or impracticable measures are introduced whose immediate effect would be to deprive thousands of these workers of their livelihood and thereby further aggravate the present unemployment situation.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I understand the circumlocution, there is no intention of applying the Ordinance to domestic servants. But would the Par liamentary Secretary consider at least issuing regulations for guidance of good employer relations in respect of domestic servants so that the employers may have a model with which to apply.

    The Prime Minister: Come, come, Mr Marshall.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, in that respect, the Member for Anson can rest assured that though employers arc not obliged to give certain benefits to the employees under this Ordinance, but nevertheless when domestic employees are aggrieved because they are not given sufficient notice of termination of their service or -

    The Prime Minister: Or otherwise maltreated.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: - maltreated they always consult and seek the assistance of the Labour Ministry. We have always assisted them in getting sufficient compensation or adequate notice of termination of their service.

    Mr David Marshall: I had in mind rather the question of whether the Government would assist employers to recognise the limitation of hours and conditions of work, and if it does not wish to apply the provisions whether it would issue some regulations for guidance.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, domestic servants are different from factory workers. Therefore, it has to be left to the conscience of the employers

Column: 153

INCOME TAX
(Penalty for late payments)


    3. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance (a) what is the policy of the Commissioner of Inland Revenue in the exercise of his discretion in respect of the imposition of the 5 per cent penalty for late payments of income tax during the currency of the year of taxation; and (b) whether the Minister has any information as to the policy of the Comptroller of Income Tax of the Federation of Malaya in respect of similar statutory discretion.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, late payment of income tax is not a problem to wage earners and salary earners who can arrange for monthly deductions to be made from their pay to the Income Tax Office, lt is a question lacing businessmen and capitalists. It is therefore refreshing to note that the Workers' Party is taking up the cudgels for the capitalists. The Commissioner of Inland Revenue has discretion to remit penalty or extend the date of payment where there are good reasons to do so. Normally a seven days' grace is given before the fine is sent and penalty imposed. Where a taxpayer is able to de monstrate that he cannot meet payment by the due date because of his absence From Malaya or sickness or other reasonable cause, remission of penalty may be granted on the individual :merits of the case. Deferred payment is also allowed in the case of a company which has commenced trading and instalments of payment are allowed on the second year of tax as a matter of practice.

    The amount received by way of penalty in 1961 was $285,000 in Singapore. the amount in the Federation was about $259,000. I have no exact information as to the policy of the Comptroller of Income Tax in the Federation of Malaya in the exercise of statutory discretion in

Column: 154

respect of the imposition of penalty. However, to judge by the amount of penalty imposed in the two territories, I would say that one territory is not very much out of line with the other.

    Mr David Marshall: The Workers' Party is interested in justice for all. The workers or capitalists would inquire whether the Minister would consider remission of penalty where there is payment within the year of taxation. Where, for example, the taxpayer pays the 1962 tax during 1962.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Such cases would arise when new companies are being established. As I mentioned in my answer, instalments and deferred payments are allowed as a matter of practice.

    Sir, in the list of posts under Schedule A, I notice a very important omission: that whereas for the Broadcasting Division there are three posts for

Column: 155

Programme Assistants in the Budget Estimates for 1962, looking after school programmes and such like educational items, here I see no provision for a similar post. Sir, we know that as an educational medium, television is far superior to radio broadcasting or the cinema. In fact, television will reach a larger number of young people in their homes,, whereas in the case of a cinema theatre, they must go to the theatre and buy tickets. In the case of television, children can just press certain buttons or turn certain knobs and there the film will be brought to their own homes. If, therefore, in a television programme the films shown are not suitable for our young people, then I am afraid the object of the Government in helping the young people will be defeated. In view of the fact that more than half of the people of Singapore are young people, I should think that posts similar to those provided for the Broadcasting Division should also be provided here. Very likely it may be due to an oversight because there are three phases, and this being only the first phase, maybe the thought was that it was not necessary to include it since there will be just a three-hour programme and only one hour will be for the news and the rest will be for films. But the selection of the films then becomes a very important thing unless the Government is going to invite the Programme Assistants in charge of Schools from the Broadcasting Division to assist also in the Television Section until such time as they are able to provide for separate posts for Programme Assistants in charge of Schools. Sir, I draw attention to this omission so that the Government will remedy it so as to prevent the wrong type of films from being televised with harmful effects to the young.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): If it please you, Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to inquire whether Government would consider allocating one channel of television for use by an independent nonprofit authority to be appointed in accordance with statutory provisions so that the people of Singapore can have the opportunity of at least one channel where they can get honest news and views.

    We are conscious that the philosophy of the Government with reference to Radio Singapore is that they are perfectly entitled to utilise it for biased propaganda purposes and, in fact, for party purposes. All we ask at this juncture - recognising that it is too much to ask that an organisation of such vital importance to the nation for the dissemination of news and views should be in independent hands - we wish to inquire whether they will permit one channel, not depriving themselves of anything, but to permit one channel to be used and paid for by a non-profit independent authority appointed in accordance with provisions of a statute to that effect.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, I fully share the fears expressed by the Member for Tanglin that care should be taken to see that morally undesirable films are not transmitted over the television network.

    Mr David Marshall: What about news?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I will come to that in due course. The Member for Anson must really learn to contain his impatience. Then there might be a better co-ordination between his tongue and his mind.

    Now, as I say, I fully agree with the sentiments expressed by the Member for Tanglin. But I think he is technically wrong in saying that there has been an omission in respect of the establishment of a television station. Broadcasting is broadcasting, and television is completely a different activity. Also one must not he too hypnotised by

Column: 157

words. We may call in the broadcasting service a grade of officers, programme assistants. In the television service they may be doing similar duties but under different names. May I refer the hon. Member for Tanglin to the grade of producers - 10 producers?

    An hon. Member: What do they produce? Lux Soap?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: They are Division I posts and none of them are programme assistants. Also there is the Chief Executive (Services), Grade F, and the Chief, Production Facilities and Films. In this hierarchy there will be officers whose responsibility it is to vet and arrange programmes to ensure certain standards of taste and decency.

    Now as for the Member for Havelock, these posts will be advertised when men are required. In fact, two months ago some lost have been advertised and the Public Service Commission have made selections for some of those and are making selections for others.

    The Member for Arson now wants an independent television service. How nice, Mr Speaker, Sir, if we can afford this sort of thing. He says the authority should be independent, non-profit making. But the trouble with this sort of venture is that when you have a fairly small number of receiving audience, there may well be a loss. It is not a question of making a profit, but avoiding losses. Our calculation is that the television service will make losses of several million dollars a year for quite some time before it recoups losses through advertising revenue licensing fees. So if the Member for Anson can let me know, in my capacity as Minister for Finance, not in my capacity as Acting Minister for Culture, any philanthropic organisation which is prepared to shoulder part of the losses that we are going to incur, then I shall be delighted to receive his suggestion.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam (Choa Chu Kang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe that the Four-Year Plan of the

Column: 158

Government can only have this part concerning T.V. materialised. We also know that in carrying out the T.V. services, the Government is trying to help itself with political propaganda and therefore, at the present juncture, the Government has stepped up its speed in setting up a temporary station in Bukit Batok in order to facilitate the propaganda work of the P.A.P. Therefore, I hope that the Acting Minister for Culture will assure this House that the T.V. service will not be taken advantage of for the purpose of political propaganda of the P.A.P.

    The second point I would like to find out from the Acting Minister for Culture concerns this. As far as I know, there are two surveying teams, one from New Zealand and the other from Japan. Can the Minister concerned tell the House whether in, the future T.V. service which country will be responsible for the assistance given to the T.V. service in Singapore?

    Mr David Marshall: Is the Minister not aware that, in fact, on television it is possible to have several channels, and an additional channel to the one proposed would not entail proportionately equal expense, and would he be prepared to consider the question of renting a channel to an independent television body? Would Government consider bringing in a Bill to create such an independent television body?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the only so-called independent television bodies who may be interested in running either the whole or part of the television service would be commercial companies who will want to make use of the facilities purely to make profits, if there is any question of renting out a studio room or television time to them, it is obvious that the only consideration between them and the Government would be just how much money they would make.

    I do not think that is the sort of independent television authority that the Member for Anson is thinking of. On the other hand, if he is thinking of something independent, like the British

Column: 159

Broadcasting Corporation, then the question is: who is going to put out the money to pay for what can be fairly substantial losses in the first few years of operations? So until we get clear answers to these problems, I do not think it is worthwhile to pursue the subject here.

    The Member for Choa Chu Kang expresses fears that this would be used as unfair propaganda. He is entitled to his views, but we do not share them. So I do not intend to pursue this argument further. As for assistance from abroad, it is true that we have two missions; one is from Japan and that is concerned mainly with the technical aspects of setting up a television service - where should the site of the transmitting station be; how fast can it expand; and whether the cost could be covered up in the long run, and so on and so forth. The Australian experts came here to advise us on the details of setting up the service.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): New Zealand.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: New Zealand. The details of setting up the service were, e.g., what staff to recruit, what equipment to buy, how to tender for them, and so on and so forth. We shall, of course, get the benefit of expert assistance from whatever source is available. But we are at the same time training our own local personnel in these new techniques, and every year anything between half a dozen and a dozen technicians are being sent abroad for study and training.

    Mr David Marshall: I am sorry to pursue this, Mr Speaker, but it seems only to be partly understood and I do ask the indulgence of this House since it is a matter of some importance. The Minister did refer to the British Broadcasting Corporation. But, of course, he is aware, as we all are, that in the United Kingdom the potent influence of the radio and television is not in the hands of Government or of any political Party. It is, in fact, in the hands of a non-profit public body created by statute. I appreciate the Government in

Column: 160

the circumstances it finds itself in, and I will elaborate no further their wish to maintain control of both radio and television. But could we not create an independent radio and television body by statute empowering it to rent at a rental paying the Government for a wavelength on the air and a channel in respect of television? And they could recoup themselves by power to take in advertisements. These have been tried out and have been found successful in other countries. As I have pointed out, the additional cost of a channel in television is not proportionate to the original cost of establishment, and it could easily be borne by the advertisements which would be attracted to this independent television channel. Would the Government consider, at least, and investigate the possibilities of the creation of such a body?

    The Prime Minister: From time to time we are indebted to Members of the Opposition for making valuable contributions to the problems that confront us. I am quite sure if the Member for Anson will elaborate on his plan and put it on a document, it will receive proper consideration.

    It is one thing just striking a bright idea across the sky, but it is another thing formulating it in a coherent, practical and feasible manner. I am quite sure the Member for Anson is capable of putting it on a document, both the structural consideration of creating an independent body and the running of one channel in the same studios. I do not know myself how these things are done, how the B.B.C. and the I.T.F. do it. I am told they have two completely different outfits - one set of studios run by the B.B.C. and another one run by the commercial T.V. outfit. These are problems which I do not think either the Minister for Finance (in his capacity as Minister for Finance or otherwise) or the Minister for Culture is in a position to speak with any authority, let alone myself; but no doubt the Member for Anson has spent some time before he makes the suggestion of just hiring out one channel, and if he will spell out all the

Column: 161

implications, I give him the undertaking that it will receive proper consideration and a proper reply.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to express a hope that the Minister will give an answer to my question, i.e. that the future T.V. service should not be taken advantage of by the Government for political purposes.

He objects to Malaysia, we like Malaysia; and if we want to propagate the idea of Malaysia, we do it. That may be one objection, and I consider that as an invalid objection.

    Second, he may say that if the Government puts up posters, then other people can put up posters. Well, other people can put up posters. On the other hand, if they instigate school kids to put up posters at 3 o'clock in the morning, then they are merely looking for trouble. So that may be the second

objection - that if we put up posters, and they should be putting up anti-posters, then I say that there is provision for that sort of thing.

    Now, the third objection could be that he does not want posters to be put up at all. There is great merit in that proposal. I mean, in a well ordered and rational society, appeals through propaganda such as posters, advertisements and so on will be completely unnecessary. In fact, no country in the world has reached the stage of being completely well ordered and perfectly rational. Therefore, these appeals to human reason, to human emotion perhaps, through various media of publicity are necessary.
